verses.text: I urge first of all that requests, prayers, intercessions, and thanksgivings be made for all people,
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes various forms of prayer, highlighting not just one type but a comprehensive spiritual discipline (requests, prayers, intercessions, thanksgivings). The call to pray for all reveals a universality in Christian charity and worship, resonating with early apostolic traditions.

verses.text: for kings and all who are in high positions, so that we may lead a quiet and peaceful life in all godliness and dignity.
verses.comment: Paul instructs believers to pray for those in authority, showing an understanding of the church's relationship to society. A peaceful Christian life is closely associated with godliness and dignity, mirroring the biblical call to honor authority while maintaining integrity (see Rom. 13:1-7).

verses.text: This is good and pleasing in the sight of God our Savior,
verses.comment: The prayers offered for all are described as both good and pleasing to God, drawing a direct connection between intercessory prayer and divine favor. 'God our Savior' highlights God's saving will, which is a recurring theme (Titus 2:10-11).

verses.text: who desires all people to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth.
verses.comment: This verse expresses God's universal salvific will and emphasizes that the knowledge of truth is united to salvation. Theological traditions consistently interpret this as reflecting the necessity for all to embrace the fullness of revealed truth for salvation. See also 2 Peter 3:9, Ezekiel 18:23.

verses.text: For there is one God and one mediator between God and humanity, the man Christ Jesus,
verses.comment: Christ is emphasized as the sole mediator, referencing His unique priestly and intercessory role (see Heb. 7:25). The singularity of God (Deut. 6:4) connects with the oneness of Christ’s mediatorship, rooted in His incarnation as 'the man Christ Jesus.' This verse upholds the necessity of both Christ's divine and human nature in the work of salvation (cf. John 14:6).

verses.text: who gave Himself as a ransom for all, the testimony given at the proper time.
verses.comment: The language of Christ giving Himself as a 'ransom for all' directly echoes Jesus’ own words (Matt. 20:28; Mark 10:45). 'For all' underlines a universal redemption, offered freely. The 'testimony' points towards the apostolic preaching of this mystery at God’s appointed time.

verses.text: For this I was appointed a herald and an apostle—I am telling the truth, I am not lying—a teacher of the Gentiles in faith and truth.
verses.comment: Paul affirms his role as apostle to the Gentiles, designated specifically for the proclamation of the faith. This triple title (herald, apostle, teacher) affirms the authority and universal mission of apostolic leadership in passing on the fullness of truth (Acts 9:15).

verses.text: Therefore, I want the men in every place to pray, lifting up holy hands without anger or quarrelling.
verses.comment: The phrase 'lifting up holy hands' recalls priestly imagery in the Old Testament (Ps. 134:2). Freedom from anger or division is underlined as a requirement for pleasing prayer and worship, reflecting the need for unity and purity of heart within the Christian assembly (Matt. 5:23-24).

verses.text: Likewise, I want women to adorn themselves in respectable clothing, with modesty and self-control, not with braided hair and gold or pearls or costly attire,
verses.comment: Paul urges inner virtue over external display, paralleling Peter’s similar call to modesty and self-control (1 Pet. 3:3-4). This reflects a consistent apostolic teaching about the importance of humility and the heart’s disposition in worship.

verses.text: but with what is proper for women who profess reverence for God—good works.
verses.comment: The apostolic tradition repeatedly connects genuine worship and piety to a life marked by good works (Matt. 5:16). The emphasis on actions over appearance ties Christian practice to both faith and charity (see also Titus 2:3-5).

verses.text: Let a woman learn quietly with all submissiveness.
verses.comment: Paul’s instructions here are culturally situated but speak to an ordered structure within public worship and teaching (cf. 1 Cor. 14:34-35). The tone is not about denial of worth but about a participatory order in the worship assembly. Many Christians see spiritual meaning in the distinction of roles within the spiritual family.

verses.text: I do not permit a woman to teach or to exercise authority over a man; rather, she is to remain quiet.
verses.comment: Paul reaffirms an established order for teaching and authority within the community, consistent with his other letters. This has been interpreted as a key passage for maintaining the structure of leadership in Christian worship (see also 1 Tim. 3:2).

verses.text: For Adam was formed first, then Eve;
verses.comment: Paul grounds the order of worship roles in the order of creation as described in Genesis. This reflects a theological understanding of creation and the human family structure as foundational to Christian practice and ecclesial order.

verses.text: and Adam was not deceived, but the woman was deceived and became a transgressor.
verses.comment: Paul references the Genesis account of the fall (Gen. 3:6), noting the consequences of disordered roles and the impact of Eve’s deceivability. This underlines the importance of obedience and the need for humility in spiritual life. See also 2 Cor. 11:3.

verses.text: But she will be saved through childbearing—if they continue in faith and love and holiness with self-control.
verses.comment: This passage has been interpreted spiritually and literally. Spiritually, some see a reference to the pivotal role of women in bringing forth salvation—most clearly fulfilled in the birth of Christ through Mary (see Luke 1:42-45). Literally, Paul affirms the sanctifying value of family life when combined with perseverance in faith and holiness. The ongoing emphasis on holiness, love, and self-control highlights the transformative power of grace within everyday life.
